FRANKENSTEIN;
OR,
THE MODERN PROMETHEUS.

BY MARY WOLLSTONECRAFT SHELLEY

LONDON:
PRINTED FOR LACKINGTON, HUGHES, HARDING, MAVOR, & JONES,
FINSBURY SQUARE.
1818.

files.name: page-001.pdf.ref.json
files.content:
Letter I

To Mrs. Saville, England.

St. Petersburgh, Dec. 11th, 17—.

You will rejoice to hear that no disaster has accompanied the commencement of an enterprise which you have regarded with such evil forebodings. I arrived here yesterday, and my first task is to assure my dear sister of my welfare and increasing confidence in the success of my undertaking.

I am already far north of London, and as I walk in the streets of Petersburgh, I feel a cold northern breeze play upon my cheeks, which braces my nerves and fills me with delight.

files.name: page-002.pdf.ref.json
files.content: Do you understand this feeling? This breeze, which has travelled from the regions towards which I am advancing, gives me a foretaste of those icy climes. Inspirited by this wind of promise, my daydreams become more fervent and vivid. I try in vain to be persuaded that the pole is the seat of frost and desolation; it ever presents itself to my imagination as the region of beauty and delight.

files.name: page-003.pdf.ref.json
files.content:
Letter II

To Mrs. Saville, England.

Archangel, 28th March, 17—.

How slowly the time passes here, encompassed as I am by frost and snow! Yet a second step is taken towards my enterprise. I have hired a vessel and am occupied in collecting my sailors; those whom I have already engaged appear to be men on whom I can depend and are certainly possessed of dauntless courage.

files.name: page-004.pdf.ref.json
files.content:
Chapter I

I am by birth a Genevese, and my family is one of the most distinguished of that republic. My ancestors had been for many years counsellors and syndics, and my father had filled several public situations with honour and reputation. He was respected by all who knew him for his integrity and indefatigable attention to public business.

files.name: page-005.pdf.ref.json
files.content:
He passed his younger days perpetually occupied by the affairs of his country; a variety of circumstances had prevented his marrying early, nor was it until the decline of life that he became a husband and the father of a family.

As the circumstances of his marriage illustrate his character, I cannot refrain from relating them.

files.name: page-006.pdf.ref.json
files.content:
Chapter II

We were brought up together; there was not quite a year difference in our ages. I need not say that we were strangers to any species of disunion or dispute. Harmony was the soul of our companionship, and the diversity and contrast that subsisted in our characters drew us nearer together.

files.name: page-007.pdf.ref.json
files.content: Elizabeth was of a calmer and more concentrated disposition; but, with all my ardour, I was capable of a more intense application and was more deeply smitten with the thirst for knowledge. She busied herself with following the aerial creations of the poets; and in the majestic and wondrous scenes which surrounded our Swiss home.

# Manuscript Notes

This is a partial manuscript of Mary Shelley's "Frankenstein" (1818 edition).

## Structure

- Frame narrative begins with Robert Walton's letters
- Victor Frankenstein's story begins in Chapter I
- The novel uses a nested narrative structure

## This Collection

Contains:
- Title page
- Letters I-II (Walton's letters to his sister)
- Chapters I-II (Victor's early life)

## Editorial Notes

The 1818 edition differs significantly from the 1831 revised edition.
